description: The Crustdata API gives you programmatic access to firmographic and growth metrics data for companies across the world from more than 16 datasets (Linkedin headcount, Glassdoor, Instagram, G2, Web Traffic, Apple App Store reviews, Google Play Store, News among others). This documentation describes various available API calls and schema of the response. If you have any questions, please reach out to [abhilash@crustdata.com](mailto:abhilash@crustdata.com).
$auth_token: Reach out to abhilash@crustdata.com get an authorization token (API key) .

data_api.description: This endpoint enriches company data by retrieving detailed information about one or multiple companies using either their domain, name, or ID.

company_domain.description: The domain(s) of the company(ies) you want to retrieve data for.

company_name.description: The name(s) of the company(ies) you want to retrieve data for.
company_name.constraints: comma-separated list, up to 25 names; use double quotes if names contain commas

company_linkedin_url.description: The LinkedIn URL(s) of the company(ies).

company_id.description: The unique ID(s) of the company(ies) you want to retrieve data for.

fields.description: Specifies the fields you want to include in the response. Supports nested fields up to a certain level.

nested_fields.description: You can specify nested fields up to the levels defined in the response structure. Fields nested beyond the allowed levels or within lists (arrays) cannot be individually accessed.

limitations.maximum_nesting_fields: You can specify nested fields only up to the levels defined above

default_exclusion_of_certain_fields.descri[tion: Even if you have access to fields like decision_makers and founders.profiles, they will not be included in the response by default when the fields parameter is not provided. You must explicitly request these fields using the fields parameter.

limitations.unavailable_fields: If you request a field that is not available or beyond the allowed nesting level, the API will return an error indicating that the field is not available for filtering.

default_fields.top_level_non_object_fields: If you do not specify the `fields` parameter, the response will include all top-level non-object fields by default (e.g., `company_name`, `company_id`).
default_fields.object_fields: By default, the response will not include object fields like `decision_makers` and `founders.profiles`, even if you have access to them. To include these fields, you must explicitly specify them using the `fields` parameter.

additional_info.user_permissions: Access to certain fields may be restricted based on your user permissions. If you request fields you do not have access to, the API will return an error indicating unauthorized access.

enrich_realtime.description: When True and the requested company is not present in Crustdata’s database, the company is enriched within 10 minutes of the request.

example_one.use_case: Ideal for users who have one or more company website domains and need to fetch detailed profiles.
example_one.note: You can provide up to 25 domains in a comma-separated list.

example_two.use_case: Suitable for users who have one or more company names and need to retrieve detailed profiles.
example_two.note: You can provide up to 25 names in a comma-separated list. If a company name contains a comma, enclose the name in double quotes.
example_two.curl_example:
curl 'https://api.crustdata.com/screener/company?company_name="HubSpot","Google, Inc."' \
  --header 'Accept: application/json, text/plain, */*' \
  --header 'Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.9' \
  --header 'Authorization: Token $token'

example_three.use_case: Suitable for users who have one or more company Linkedin urls and need to retrieve detailed profiles.
example_three.note: You can provide up to 25 names in a comma-separated list. If a company name contains a comma, enclose the name in double quotes.

example_four.use_case: Suitable for users who have ingested one or more companies from Crustdata already and want to enrich their data by Crustdata’s company_id. Users generally use this when they want time-series data for specific companies after obtaining the company_id from the screening endpoint.
example_four.note: You can provide up to 25 IDs in a comma-separated list.

example_five.use_case: Fetch only specific fields to tailor the response to your needs.

example_six.use_case: For companies not tracked by Crustdata, you want to enrich them within 10 minutes of the request

response_structure.description: The response is a JSON array containing company objects. Below is the structure of the response up to the levels where you can filter using the fields parameter. The response provides a comprehensive profile of the company, including firmographic details, social media links, headcount data, and growth metrics.

encrichment_status.description: When you request data for a company not in our database, we start an enrichment process that takes up to 24 hours (or 10 minutes if enrich_realtime is true).

status.enriching: When you request data for a company not in our database, we start an enrichment process that takes up to 24 hours (or 10 minutes if enrich_realtime is true).
status.not_found: Enrichment failed (e.g., no website or employees). You can stop polling for this company.

screening_api.description: The company screening API request allows you to screen and filter companies based on various growth and firmographic criteria

metrics.description: An array of metric objects containing the metric name.

filters.description: An object containing the filter conditions.

op.description: The operator to apply on the conditions.

condition.description: An array of complex filter objects or basic filter objects.

column.description: The name of the column to filter.

type.description: The filter type. The value can be =>, =<, =, !=, in, (.), [.]

in.description: Exactly matches atleast one of the elements of list

allow_null.description: A Boolean flag. Whether to allow null values. The value can be true or false.

offset.description: The starting point of the result set. Default value is 0.
offset.note: To retrieve all the jobs listings, keep iterating over offset field in the payload.

count.description: The number of results to return in a single request.
count.note: Do not increase limit beyond 100 as the result will be truncated without any ordering.

problem.conditon_one: Comapnies have raised > $5,000,000 in total funding AND
problem.conditon_three: Companies have largest headcount country as USA

response.description: The response is JSON object that consists of two main components: fields and rows.
response.fields: An array of objects representing the columns in the dataset.
response.rows: An array of arrays, each representing a row of data.
response.note: The values in each of the rows elements are ordered in the same sequence as the fields in the fields array. For example, the ith value in a row corresponds to the ith field in the fields array.

parsing_steps.step: Iterate over each row in the 'rows' array
parsing_steps.description: Each row contains a list of values that corresponds to the fields listed in the 'fields' array.

parsing_steps.step: For each row, iterate over the values in that row
parsing_steps.description: Each value in the row corresponds to a specific field, identified by the 'api_name' in the 'fields' array.

parsing_steps.step: Map the value from the row to the corresponding field based on the 'api_name'
parsing_steps.description: For each value in the row, map it to the field identified by 'api_name' at the same index in the 'fields' array.

parsing_steps.step: Create an object for each row that maps 'api_name' to the respective value from the row
parsing_steps.description: For each row, create an object where the keys are 'api_name' and the values are the respective values from the row.
If a value is 'null' or missing, ensure it's handled appropriately, either by assigning a default value or keeping it as null.

identification_api.description: Given a company’s name, website or LinkedIn profile, you can identify the company in Crustdata’s database with company identification API
input: linkedIn profile url of the company

parameters.query_company_linkedin_url: LinkedIn profile url of the company

request.curl_example:
curl 'https://api.crustdata.com/screener/identify/' \
    --header 'Accept: application/json, text/plain, */*' \
    --header 'Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.9' \
    --header 'Authorization: Token $api_token' \
    --header 'Connection: keep-alive' \
    --header 'Content-Type: application/json' \
    --header 'Origin: https://crustdata.com' \
    --data '{"query_company_website": "serverobotics.com", "count": 1}'

company_id.description: A unique identifier for the company in Crustdata’s database. This value uniquely represents the company.

company_name.description: The name of the company as listed in Crustdata’s database.

company_website_domain.description: The domain name of the company's website, usually derived from the company’s LinkedIn profile page.

company_website.description: The full URL to the company’s website (e.g., 'https://www.companyname.com').

linkedin_profile_url.description: The LinkedIn profile URL for the company, linking to its official LinkedIn page.

linkedin_headcount.description: The latest headcount or employee number of the company in Crustdata’s database.

acquisition_status.description: The acquisition status of the company, which could be 'acquired' or 'null' if not applicable.

score.description: A relative score indicating how well the query parameters match the company’s data in Crustdata’s database. Higher score means better match.

auth_token.description: The authentication token used to authorize the request. It is required to access the LinkedIn Company Search API.

linkedin_sales_navigator_search_url.description: The URL from the LinkedIn Sales Navigator Accounts search, used to filter companies based on the Sales Navigator search results.

filters.description: An array of filter criteria objects, which specify the filters to apply to the LinkedIn Company Search. Filters can be categorized into text, range, and boolean filters.

filter_type.description: The type of filter to apply. Examples include 'COMPANY_HEADCOUNT', 'ANNUAL_REVENUE', etc.

type.description: The type of filter operation to apply. For text filters, it could be 'in' or 'not in'. For range filters, it could be 'between'. Boolean filters do not use 'type'.

value.description: The value(s) to filter on, which can be a single value, an array of values, or a range of values depending on the filter type.

sub_filter.description: An optional field that provides additional context for a range filter. For example, specifying the unit of currency in a revenue filter (e.g., 'USD').

COMPANY_HEADCOUNT.description: Specifies the size of the company based on the number of employees.

REGION.description: Specifies the geographical region of the company.

INDUSTRY.description: Specifies the industry of the company.

NUM_OF_FOLLOWERS.description: Specifies the number of followers a company has.

FORTUNE.description: Specifies the Fortune ranking of the company.

ACCOUNT_ACTIVITIES.description: Specifies recent account activities, such as leadership changes or funding events.
value: Senior leadership changes in last 3 months

JOB_OPPORTUNITIES.description: Specifies job opportunities available at the company.

COMPANY_HEADCOUNT_GROWTH.description: Specifies the growth of the company's headcount.

ANNUAL_REVENUE.description: Specifies the annual revenue of the company.

DEPARTMENT_HEADCOUNT.description: Specifies the headcount of specific departments within the company.

DEPARTMENT_HEADCOUNT_GROWTH.description: Specifies the growth of headcount in specific departments.

KEYWORD.description: Filters based on specific keywords related to the company.

CURRENT_COMPANY.description: Specifies the current company of the person.

CURRENT_TITLE.description: Specifies the current title of the person.

PAST_TITLE.description: Specifies the past titles held by the person.

COMPANY_HEADQUARTERS.description: Specifies the headquarters of the person's company.

COMPANY_HEADCOUNT.description: Specifies the size of the company based on the number of employees.

REGION.description: Specifies the geographical region of the person.

INDUSTRY.description: Specifies the industry of the person's company.

PROFILE_LANGUAGE.description: Specifies the language of the person's profile.

SENIORITY_LEVEL.description: Specifies the seniority level of the person.

YEARS_AT_CURRENT_COMPANY.description: Specifies the number of years the person has been at their current company.

YEARS_IN_CURRENT_POSITION.description: Specifies the number of years the person has been in their current position.

YEARS_OF_EXPERIENCE.description: Specifies the total years of experience the person has.

FIRST_NAME.description: Specifies the first name of the person.

LAST_NAME.description: Specifies the last name of the person.

FUNCTION.description: Specifies the function or role of the person.

PAST_COMPANY.description: Specifies the past companies the person has worked for.

COMPANY_TYPE.description: Specifies the type of company the person works for.

POSTED_ON_LINKEDIN.description: Specifies if the person has posted on LinkedIn.

RECENTLY_CHANGED_JOBS.description: Specifies if the person has recently changed jobs.

IN_THE_NEWS.description: Specifies if the person has been mentioned in the news.

KEYWORD.description: Filters based on specific keywords related to the person.

Optional.linkedin_sales_navigator_search_url: URL of the Sales Navigator Accounts search from the browser
Optional.filters: JSON dictionary defining the search criteria as laid out by the Crustdata filter schema.
Optional.page: Only valid when filters is not empty. When passing linkedin_sales_navigator_search_url, page should be specified in linkedin_sales_navigator_search_url itself

example_one.problem: This query retrieves people from companies with a headcount between 1,001-5,000 or more than 10,001+, with annual revenue between 1 and 500 million USD, excluding those located in the United States, and returns the second page of results

pagination.linkedin_sales_navigator_search_url: You can paginate by adding the 'page' query param to the URL. For example, 'page=2'.
pagination.filters: You can paginate by including 'page' as one of the keys in the payload.

key_points.latency: The data is fetched in real-time from LinkedIn with latency between 10 to 30 seconds.
key_points.response_schema: The response schema differs from the company data enrichment endpoint as data is fetched in real-time. Data will be enriched in Crustdata’s database within 60 minutes of the query.

linkedin_post_search.description: This endpoint retrieves recent LinkedIn posts and related engagement metrics for a specified company.Each request returns up-to 5 results per page. To paginate, increment the page query param.

request.use_case: Ideal for users who want to fetch recent LinkedIn posts and engagement data for a specific company.
request.note: You can provide one company LinkedIn URL per request.

parameters.fields: Optional: Comma separated list of fields you want in the response. Default includes all fields except 'reactors'.
parameters.limit: Optional: Limit the number of posts per page (default: 5)
parameters.post_types: Optional: Specify post types. Default: 'repost', 'original'. Options are 'original' and 'repost'.

response.description: The response provides a list of recent LinkedIn posts for the specified company, including post content, engagement metrics, and information about users who interacted with the posts.

backend_urn.description: Unique identifier for the post in LinkedIn's backend system.

share_urn.description: Unique identifier for the shared content.

share_url.description: Direct URL to the post on LinkedIn.

text.description: The full content of the post.

actor_name.description: Name of the company or person who created the post.

hyperlinks.description: Contains the external links and Company/Person LinkedIn urls mentioned in the post.

company_linkedin_urls.description: List of Company LinkedIn URLs mentioned in the post.

person_linkedin_urls.description: List of Person LinkedIn URLs mentioned in the post.

date_posted.description: Date when the post was published in 'YYYY-MM-DD' format.

total_reactions.description: Total number of reactions on the post.

total_comments.description: Total number of comments on the post.

num_shares.description: Number of times the post has been shared.

reactors.description: List of users who reacted to the post.

name.description: Full name of the person who reacted.

linkedin_profile_url.description: URL to the reactor's LinkedIn profile.

profile_image_url.description: URL to the reactor's profile image (100x100 size).

title.description: Current professional title of the reactor.

additional_info.description: Additional information, often indicating connection degree.

linkedin_profile_urn.description: Unique identifier for the reactor's LinkedIn profile.

default_position_title.description: Primary job title of the reactor.

default_position_company_linkedin_id.description: LinkedIn ID of the reactor's primary company.

default_position_is_decision_maker.description: Indicates if the reactor is in a decision-making role.

flagship_profile_url.description: Another form of the reactor's LinkedIn profile URL.

profile_picture_url.description: URL to a larger version of the reactor's profile picture (400x400 size).

headline.description: Professional headline from the reactor's LinkedIn profile.

num_of_connections.description: Number of LinkedIn connections the reactor has.

related_colleague_company_id.description: LinkedIn ID of a related company, possibly current employer.

skills.description: List of professional skills listed on the reactor's profile.

company_linkedin_id.description: LinkedIn ID of the employer company.

start_date.description: Start date of employment in ISO format.

end_date.description: End date of employment, or null if current.

rich_media.description: Currently empty, may contain media related to the job.

start_date.description: Start date of education in ISO format.

end_date.description: End date of education in ISO format.

emails.description: Known email addresses associated with the reactor.

websites.description: Currently empty, may contain personal or professional websites.

languages.description: Currently empty, may contain languages spoken.

current_title.description: Current job title, often identical to default_position_title.

default_without_reactors.description: Each successful page request without reactor data will cost 5 credits.

with_reactors.description: Each successful page request with reactor data will cost 25 credits.

page_increment.description: To fetch the next set of posts, increment the value of the `page` query parameter.

latest_posts_order.description: The most recent posts will be available on the first page, and older posts will appear on subsequent pages.

max_pages.description: Currently, a maximum of 20 pages can be fetched. For more, contact Crustdata support.

hyperlinks.description: The `hyperlinks` field contains a list of links mentioned in the post, categorized into `company_linkedin_urls`, `person_linkedin_urls`, and `other_urls`.

real_time_fetch.description: Data is fetched in real-time from LinkedIn, and the latency for this endpoint ranges between 30 to 60 seconds, depending on the number of reactions for all the posts in the page.

linkedin_keyword_post_search.description: This endpoint retrieves LinkedIn posts containing specified keywords along with related engagement metrics. Each request returns 5 posts per page. To paginate, increment the page  in the payload. authentication token auth_token for authorization.

keyword.description: The keyword or phrase to search for in LinkedIn posts.

limit.description: Limit the number of posts in a page.

sort_by.description: Defines the sorting order of the results. Can be one of the following: 'relevance' - to sort on top match, 'date_posted' - to sort on latest posts.

date_posted.description: Filters posts by the date they were posted. Can be one of the following: 'past-24h' - Posts from last 24 hours, 'past-week' - Posts from last 7 days, 'past-month' - Posts from last 30 days, 'past-quarter' - Posts from last 3 months, 'past-year' - Posts from last 1 year.

exmaple.problem: Get all the posts with “LLM evaluation”  keyword in last 3 months
exmaple.curl_solution:
curl 'https://api.crustdata.com/screener/linkedin_posts/keyword_search/' \
-H 'Accept: application/json, text/plain, /' \
-H 'Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.9' \
-H 'Authorization: Token $auth_token' \
-H 'Connection: keep-alive' \
-H 'Content-Type: application/json' \
-H 'Origin: https://crustdata.com' \
--data-raw '{
   "keyword":"LLM Evaluation",
   "page":1,
   "sort_by":"relevance",
   "date_posted":"past-quarter"
}' \
--compressed
exmaple.python_solution:
import requests

headers = {
    'Accept': 'application/json, text/plain, /',
    'Accept-Language': 'en-US,en;q=0.9',
    'Authorization': 'Token $auth_token', # replace $auth_token
    'Connection': 'keep-alive',
    'Content-Type': 'application/json',
    'Origin': 'https://crustdata.com'
}

json_data = {
   "keyword":"LLM Evaluation",
   "page":1,
   "sort_by":"relevance",
   "date_posted":"past-quarter"
}

response = requests.post('https://api.crustdata.com/screener/linkedin_posts/keyword_search/', headers=headers, json=json_data)

response.description: The response provides a list of recent LinkedIn posts for the specified company, including post content, engagement metrics, and information about users who interacted with the posts.
response.info: Refer to actor_type field to identify if the post is published by a person or a company.

credits.description: Each successful page request costs 5 credits.

pagination.description: Increment the value of `page` query param to fetch the next set of posts. Each page contains 5 posts.
pagination.note: `limit` cannot exceed 5 when `page` is provided in the payload. To retrieve posts in bulk, use the `limit` parameter (with value over 5 allowed here) without the `page` parameter.

latency.description: The data is fetched in real-time from LinkedIn and the latency for this endpoint is between 5 to 10 seconds depending on the number of posts fetched in a request.

profile_api.description: Enrich data for one or more individuals using LinkedIn profile URLs or business email addresses. This API allows you to retrieve enriched person data from Crustdata’s database or perform a real-time search from the web if the data is not available.

enrich_data_using_linkedin_or_email.description: Enrich data using LinkedIn profile URLs or business email addresses.

real_time_search.description: Option to perform a real-time search if data is not present in the database.

retrieve_up_to_25_profiles_or_emails.description: Retrieve data for up to 25 profiles or emails in a single request.

Optional.linkedin_profile_url: Comma-separated list of LinkedIn profile URLs.

enrich_realtime.description: Boolean (True or False). If set to True, performs a real-time search from the web if data is not found in the database.

fields.description: Specifies the fields you want to include in the response. Comma separated list.

mandatory_parameters.linkedin_profile_url: You must provide either linkedin_profile_url or business_email. Do not include both in the same request.

formatting.multiple_urls_emails: Multiple LinkedIn profile URLs or business emails should be comma-separated. Extra spaces or tabs before or after commas will be ignored.

fields.default_fields: If you don’t use fields, you will get all the fields in response except 'all_connections', 'linkedin_open_to_cards', 'certifications', 'honors', and 'education_background.activities_and_societies'.
fields.restricted_access: Access to certain fields may be restricted based on your user permissions. If you request fields you do not have access to, the API will return an error indicating unauthorized access.
fields.top_level_fields: Top level non-object fields are present in the response irrespective of fields.
fields.metadata_fields: Don’t include metadata fields: 'enriched_realtime', 'score', and 'query_linkedin_profile_urn_or_slug' in fields.

example_one.use_case: Ideal for users who wants to access all fields which are not provided by default

example_two.pattern: Request with all default fields AND education_background.activities_and_societies

example_three.pattern: Request with all default fields AND certifications , honors  and linkedin_open_to_cards

when_profiles_present.description: Response will include the enriched data for each LinkedIn profile.

when_profiles_not_found.description: An error message will be returned for each profile not found, with instructions to query again after 60 minutes.

enrich_realtime_false.description: If some profiles or emails are not found and 'enrich_realtime=False', an empty response will be returned for those entries. They will be auto-enriched in the background and can be queried again after 60 minutes.

enrich_realtime_true.description: If 'enrich_realtime=True' and the profile/email cannot be found via real-time search, an error message will be returned for those entries.

real_time_search.description: May take longer due to fetching data from the web.

profiles_emails_per_request.description: Up to 25 profiles or emails per request.

exceeding_limits.description: Requests exceeding this limit will be rejected with an error message.

database_enrichment.cost: 3 credits per LinkedIn profile or email.

real_time_enrichment.cost: 5 credits per LinkedIn profile or email (when enrich_realtime=True).

valid_input.description: Ensure all LinkedIn URLs and email addresses are correctly formatted. Invalid inputs result in validation errors.

mutually_exclusive_parameters.description: Do not include both linkedin_profile_url and business_email in the same request.

independent_processing.description: Each profile or email is processed independently. Found entries are returned immediately. Not found entries trigger the enrichment process (if enrich_realtime=False).

people_search.description: Search for people profiles based on either a direct LinkedIn Sales Navigator search URL or a custom search criteria as a filter. This endpoint allows you to retrieve detailed information about individuals matching specific criteria.Each request returns upto 25 results. To paginate, update the page number of the Sales Navigator search URL and do the request again. In the request payload, either set the url of the Sales Navigator Leads search from your browser in the parameter `linkedin_sales_navigator_search_url` or specify the search criteria as a JSON object in the parameter `filters`
